d:chapter.d:title: Complex Numbers Problems
d:chapter.d:para: This is split into parts because MathJaX takes a lot of time to render if there is lots of Math on the same page.
Find the square root of following complex numbers:

d:orderedlist.d:listitem: Find the square root of x2y2+y2x2+12i(xy+yx)+3116

Find the square root of
x2y2+y2x2−1i(xy−yx)−94

Find the square root of
x2+1x2+4ix-1x-6
Find i-i

d:chapter.d:para: Simplify the following form of A+iB

d:orderedlist.d:listitem: Find the complex number z such that z2+z=0
Show that for z∈C,|z|=0 if and only if z=0
If z1 and z1 are 1-i and 2+7i find Imz1z2z1¯
If z=1 then prove that z-1z+1 is purely imaginary.
If z-i<1 then prove that |z+12-6i|<14.
If z+6=2z+3 then prove that z=3
If a-ib=x-iy then prove that a+ib=x+iy.

Show that the equation
A2x-a+B2x-b+...+H2x-h=x+l,
where, A,B,...,H;a,b,...,h and l are real; cannot have imaginary roots.
Show that a unimodular complex number, not purely real can always be expressed as c+ic-i for some real c.

If the expression
sinx2+cosx2-itanx1+2isinx2
is real, then find all the possible set of values for x.
Find the conjugate, modulus and argument of 3+2i.
Put a+ibx-iy in polar form.

d:chapter.d:para: For any two complex numbers z1 and z2 prove that

d:orderedlist.d:listitem:
z1=1 and z2=1 then prove that
z1+z2=1z1+1z2
If z-2=2z-1 then show that z2=43Re(z)
If a+ib3=x+iy then prove that ax+by=4(x2-y2)
If x+iy=a+ibc+id then prove that (x2+y2)2=a2+b2c2+d2
If 32+cosθ+isinθ=a+ib then prove that a2+b2=4a-3
If 2z-1=z-2 then prove that z=1
If x is real and 1-ix1+ix=m+in then prove that m2+n2=1
m+in=x+iyx-iy,wherex,y,m,n are real and x+iy≠0 and m+in≠0 then prove that m2+n2=1
If 1+ixa1+ixb1+ixc...=A+iB then prove that 1+x2a21+x2b21+x2c2...=A2+B2
Let z1 and z2 be complex numbers such that z1≠z2 and z1=z2. If z1 has positive real part and z2 has negative imaginary part then prove that z1+z2z1-z2 is either zero or purely imaginary.
For complex numbers z1=x1+iy1 and z2=x2+iy2 the notation of z1∩z2 is valid if x1≤x2 and y1≤y2. Show that for all complex numbers z with 1∩z we have 1-z1+z∩0.
If a>0,z|z|+az+1=0, show that z is a negative real number.
Find the range of real number α for which the equation z+α|z-1|+2i=0;z=x+iy has a solution. Also, find the solution.
For every real number a≥0, find all the complex numbers satisfying the equation az-4az+1+ia=0
Express (x2+a2)(x2+b2)(x2+c2) as sum of two square.
If equation z2+αz+β=0 has a real root then prove that (αβ¯−βα¯)(α¯−α)=(β−β¯)2
Dividing f(z) by z−i, we get i as remainder and if we divide by z+i, we get 1+i as remainder. Find the remainder upon division of f(z) by z2+1
If iz3+z2−z+i=0, then show that |z|=1
If α and β are any two complex numbers then show that |α+α2−β2|+|α−α2−β2|=|α+β|+|α−β|

If z1=a+ib and z2=c+id are complex numbers such that |z1|=|z2|=1 and Re(z1z2¯)=0 then show that the pair of complex numbers ω1=a+ic and ω2=b+id satisfy
|ω1|=|ω2|=1
Re(ω1ω2¯)=0
Prove that |z1−z21−z1z2¯|<1 if |z1|<1,|z2|<1
Let z1=10+6i and z2=4+6i. If z is any complex number such that z−z1z−z2=π4, then prove that |z−7−9i|=32.
Find all complex numbers z for which arg(3z−6−3i2z−8−6i)=π4 and |z−3+i=3|
If z≤1,|w|≤1, show that |z−w|2≤(|z|−|w|)2+(Arg(z)−Arg(w))2

If z is any non-zero complex number, show that
|z|z|−1|≤|argz|
|z−1|≤||z|−1|+|z||argz|
If |z+1z|=a, where z is a complex number and a>0, find the greatest and least value of |z|.
If z1,z2 are complex numbers and c is a positive number prove that |z1+z2|2<(1+c)|z1|2+(1+1c)|z2|2
Let z1,z2 be any two complex numbers and a,b be two real numbers such that a2+b2≠0. Prove that |z1|2+|z2|2−|z12+z22|≤2|az1+bz2|2a2+b2≤|z1|2+|z2|2+|z12+z22|
If b+ic=(1+a)z and a2+b2+c2=1, prove that a+ib1+c=1+iz1−iz, where a,b,c are real numbers and zis a complex number.
If a,b,c,...,k are all n real roots of the equation xn+p1xn−1+p2xn−2+...+pn−1x+pn=0, where p1,p2,...,pn are real, show that (1+a2)(1+b2)...(1+k2)=(1−p2+p4)2+(p1−p3+...)2
If f(x)=x4−8x3+4x2+4x+39 and f(3+2i)=a+ib, find a:b
If z1,z2,z3 be the vertices of an equilateral triangle, show that 1z1−z2+1z2−z3+1z3−z1=0 or z12+z22+z32=z1z2+z2z3+z3z1
If z12+z22-2z1z2cosθ=0, show that the points z1,z2 and the origin are the vertices of an isosceles triangle.
Let A and B be two complex numbers such that AB+BA=1, prove that the triangle formed by origin and these two points is equilateral.
Prove that the area of triangle formed by three complex numbers z1,z2,z3 is |∑(z2−z3)|z1|24iz1|
If n>1 then show that the roots of the equation zn=(z+1)n are collinear.
If A,B,C, and D are four complex number then show that AD.BC≤BD.CA+CD.AB
If a,b∈R and and a,b≠0 then show that the equation of line joining a and bi is (12a−i2b)z+(12a+i2b)z¯=1.

If z1 and z2 are two complex number such that |z1|=|z2|+|z1−z2|
then show that arg z1−arg z2=2nπ
where n∈I
If z=z1.z2.....zn, prove that arg z−(arg z1+arg z2+...+arg zn)=2nπ where n∈I
Let A,B,C,D,E be points in the complex plane representing the complex numbers z1,z2,z3,z4,z5 respectively. If (z3−z2)z4=(z1−z2)z5 prove that △ABC and △DOE are similar.

Let z and z0 are two complex numbers and the numbers z,z0,zz0¯,1 are represented by points P,P0,Q,A respectively. If |z|=1, show that the triangles POP0 and AOQ are congruent or |z−z0|=|zz0¯−1| where AO represents origin.
If the line segment joining z1 and z2 is divided by P and Q in the ratio a:b internally and externally then find OP2+OQ2 where O is the origin.
Let z1,z2,z3 be three complex numbers and a,b,c be real numbers not all zero such that a+b+c=0 and az1+bz2+cz3=0, then show that z1,z2,z3 are collinear.
If z1+z2+...+zn=0, prove that if a line passes through origin then all these do not lie on the same side of line provided the points do not lie on the line.

Suppose the points z1,z2,...,z2(zi≠0) all lie on one side of a line drawn through origin of the complex plane. Prove that the same if true of the points 1z1,1z2,...,1zn. Moreover, show that z1+z2+...+zn≠0 and 1z1+1z2+...+1z2≠0
The points z1=9+12i and z2=6−8i are given on a complex plane. Find the equation of the bisector of the angle formed by the vector representing z1 and z2

If the vertices of a triangle ABC are z1,z2,z3, then show that the orthocenter of the △ABC is asecAz2+bsecBz2+csecCz3asecA+bsecB+csecC or z1tanA+z2tanB+z3tanCtanA+tanB+tanC or z=∑z12(z2¯−z3¯)+∑|z1|2(z2−z3)∑(z1z2¯−z2z1¯) where z is the orthocenter and a,b,c are sides.
If the vertices of a triangle ABC are z1,z2,z3, then show that the circumcenter of the △ABC is z1sin2A+z2sin2B+z2sin2Csin2A+sin2B+sin2C or z=∑z1z1¯z2−z3∑z1¯(z2−z3) where z is the circumcenter.
ABCD is a rhombus described in clockwise direction, vertices are given by z1,z2,z3,z4 respectively and ∠CBA=2π/3. Show that 23z2=(3−i)z1+(3+i)z3 and 23z4=(3−i)z3+(3+i)z1
